text.text:
These days you can't have brunch without getting snap happy over a bit of sourdough. Do you find yourself wishing for a simpler time? Breakfast time, for instance? 

Enter the greasy spoon - an endangered species where you can grab a reliable plate of ham, eggs and chips for a few bob, with a piping hot mug of nostalgia. The usual clientele don't give a fuck about their Insta feed. They've been ordering the same thing for 30 years and they're feeling dead chuffed about it.

tip.text:
Pretty weird to find a cafe that still has the original wood paneling and art deco touch these days, but this proper East End caff does. E. Pellicci serves up no-nonsense grub - fry ups, minestrone, bread pudding - with that kind of food and some of the loveliest staff around, this family owned cafe is pretty much a miracle hangover cure.

The food is comforting but it's the warm welcome that keeps us coming back. It's been in the same family since the 1900s, and the food is still lovingly prepared by mamma and served by her kiddies. Aww.

text.text:
Pretty weird to find a cafe that still has the original wood paneling and art deco touch these days, but this proper East End caff does. E. Pellicci serves up no-nonsense grub - fry-ups, minestrone, bread pudding. 

With that kind of food and some of the loveliest staff around, this family-owned cafe is pretty much a miracle hangover cure. It's been in the same family since the 1900s, and the food is still lovingly prepared by mamma and served by her kiddies. Aww.

tip.text:
Tucked behind bright yellow frontage, on a road of multicoloured houses, this busy, bustley local has all the welcoming feels of a true Italian caff. It's pretty darn cosy (read small), and always filled with loyal regulars. Share a table with them and they might even let you in their posse.

Early risers can be seen enjoying a generous full English to set them up for a busy day, while later in the day locals lean over huge plates of spaghetti. And Mario? Well he's pretty proud of what his father built (and named after him) so he's sticking with it for now.

text.text:
This busy, bustley local has all the welcoming feels of a true Italian caff. It's pretty darn cosy (read small), and always filled with loyal regulars. Share a table with them and they might even let you in their posse. 

Early risers can be seen enjoying a generous full English to set them up for a busy day, while later in the day locals lean over huge plates of spaghetti. And Mario? Well he's pretty proud of what his father built (and named after him) so he's sticking with it for now.

tip.text:
Ask any local so-and-so and they'll tell you, Maggie's is a firm favourite in these ends. Best known for its all-day brekkies, they also serve up hearty evening meals of slow-cooked lamb shanks with plenty o' gravy. And of course, like any caff worth its bread and butter, all manner of potatoes: mashed, jacket, roast, chips, and boiled.

Set up in 83, this caff is about as welcoming as it gets. Might have something to do with owner, Maggie Khondoker's homely Cork accent, the constant supply of strong tea or the lashings of custard that drown a slice of apple pie. All we know is it's a local institution with builders and mothers alike, and we fell pretty hard for it.

text.text:
Ask any local so-and-so and they'll tell you, Maggie's is a firm favourite in these ends. Best known for its all-day brekkies, they also serve up hearty evening meals of slow-cooked lamb shanks with plenty o' gravy.

Set up in 83, this caff is about as welcoming as it gets. Might have something to do with owner, Maggie Khondoker's homely Cork accent, the constant supply of strong tea or the lashings of custard that drown a slice of apple pie.

tip.text:
Like a bit of cheap and cheerful do ya? Well this one's for you then. It's a legit 1960s caff with all the period blue and white tiling, murals, wooden panelling, formica tables, and original ceiling to prove it. Yep, you've gone back in time to a simpler time.

Three generations of the same Italian family have been laying on the top quality service and dolling out reliable brekkies for decades. Go for mix-and-match full English, or a classic plate of shepherd’s pie, ham, egg and chips, or liver and bacon - all in mighty generous portion sizes. Finish with apple pie or some sort of Italian pud, grab a cup o' chai, and settle down next to a charming elderly gent reading the paper. Oh and leave your phone in your pocket for this one.

text.text: This 1960s caff is legit and has all the period blue and white tiling, formica tables and murals to prove it. Three generations of the same Italian family have been laying on the top quality service for decades. Go for mix-and-match full English, or a classic plate of ham, egg and chips - all in mighty generous portions of course. Then grab a cup o' chai, and settle down next to a charming elderly gent reading the paper. Oh and leave your phone in your pocket for this one.

tip.text:
It's easy to get bogged down in fancy Islington brunch spots but then you might miss glorious nuggets of timeless optimism like Alpino. Not much has changed since 1959 and that is a huge part of the charm. You want avocados? You can fuck right off. What you will find though is plenty of classic caff fare and quality Italian dishes. Pasta is always a reliable choice - and pretty sick value if you ask us. So you might share a table with some local Tom, Dick or Larry. This could add to your banks of jokes stories, or just make for a nice chat.

We stick to the classic breakfast combos (including a veggie with bubble and squeak) or go rogue with a salt beef sarnie, served with chips. Happiness, comfort and full bellies lie on the road ahead.

text.text:

What you will find though is plenty of classic caff fare and quality Italian dishes. Pasta is always a reliable choice - and pretty sick value if you ask us. So you might share a table with some local Tom, Dick or Larry. This could add to your banks of jokes stories, or just make for a nice chat.

tip.text:
'Oh it wasn't like this in my day...' You may have heard about the sad demise of the classic British caff, and maybe thought you didn't care. That was until you stumbled upon one like this, in your hour of need, and they replenished you with a fry-up like no other.

Andrew's Restaurant is a good option, with plenty of original features (think formica tables and sturdy wooden chairs). Food-wise, they're keeping things simple with a strong selection of full English brekkies, hot jacky ps and fresh sarnies. And the tea? It comes piping hot, the colour of brick, in a mug, and with a smile.

text.text:

Andrew's Restaurant has plenty of original features and a strong selection of full English brekkies, hot jacky ps and fresh sarnies. And the tea? It comes piping hot, the colour of brick, in a mug, and with a smile.

tip.text:
Camberwell is in a stage of transition. Gentrification is on the up and the remnants of old cambers are sinking into legend. Mary's though is alive and well - maybe it's the poached duck eggs that saved her, the subtlest nod to brunch trends.

Apart from that, all is trad - breakfasts are large, reasonably priced and cooked to perfection. Eggs are just the right amount of runny and there's nothing scary about the sausages either. The black board walks you through the combinations of brekkie, omelettes, burgers, sarnies and mains. Liver, chips and onions for you? It's about as classic British caff as it gets.
